FacilityName: Rohm and Haas Chemicals LLC, Lone Star Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary         ExecSumm.data
Executive Summary for Rohm and Haas Chemicals LLC, Lone Star
Plant

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response
At Rohm and Haas Chemicals LLC, Lone Star Plant, we are
committed to operating and maintaining our process in a safe
and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental
release prevention programs and emergency response planning
programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the
public as well as protection of the environment.  This
document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk
management activities that we have designed and implemented,
including:

-A description of our facility and use of substances
regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
-A summary of results from our assessment of the potential
offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
-An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
-A five-year accident history of accidental release of
chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule

Our facility produces a water based Acrylic Emulsion used in
the Industrial Coatings Industry as well as some products
used for paper coatings.  In our process, we use the
following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the
potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the
event of a substantial accidental release.

Toxic Chemicals:

Vinyl Acetate
VA is received via rail car and is stored as a pressurized
liquid in horizontal tanks capable of holding 165,000lbs.
(we have 2 tanks)  Procedures are in place so that we do not
offload a rail car until it can fit into the tanks.  There
are several manual and automatic safety devices in place,
and the tanks are vented to a flare system.  All offloading
is done via a closed loop system so that all vapors are
contained.  All offloading is continuously monitored until
complete, and there is a containment under the railcar which
is piped to a secondary containment pit which can be
isolate

d and/or sampled prior to pumping it to the waste
treatment facility.

Acrylonitrile
AN  is received via rail car and is stored as a pressurized
liquid in horizontal tanks capable of holding 165,000lbs.
Procedures are in place so that we do not offload a rail car
until it can fit into the tanks.  There are several manual
and automatic safety devices in place, and the tanks are
vented to a flare system.  All offloading is done via a
closed loop system so that all vapors are contained.  All
offloading is continuously monitored until complete, and
there is a containment under the railcar which is piped to a
secondary containment pit which can be isolated and/or
sampled prior to pumping it to the waste treatment facility.

Our accidental release prevention program and our
contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the
hazards that are posed to our employees, the public and the
environment by our use of these chemicals.

Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios
EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about
the worst-case release scenario(s) and alternative release
scenario(s) for our facility.  The following brief summaries
of these scenarios including information about the key
administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the
exposure distances for each scenario:

Worst-case Release Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemical

Acrylonitrile

Even though the tank can hold up to 176000 pounds, we use an
inventory method that we only order 40000 pounds at a time
and keep the inventory low.  The worst case would be a
complete rupture of a tank that would result in a release of
the entire tank (if it was full) in 10 minutes.  This would
produce a cloud that would not reach the residence or
schools in Deer Park, but would reach the neighboring sites,
as well as the San Jacinto Battleground/Monument State Park.
It would also reach the Houston Ship Channel.

Alternative Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxi

c Chemical

Vinyl Acetate
The Alternative case for Vinyl Acetate is a line/gasket
leak.  This will produce a cloud that will not reach into
the city of Deer Park or any recreational area or park, or
have an impact on public receptors other that neighboring
industrial plants in our area.

Acrylonitrile
The Alternative case for Vinyl Acetate is a line/gasket
leak.  This will produce a cloud that will not reach into
the city of Deer Park or any recreational area or park, or
have an impact on public receptors other that neighboring
industrial plants in our area.

We are using this information to help us ensure that our
emergency response plan and the community emergency response
plan address all reasonable contingency cases.  All of this
information including all details have been shared with the
general public in the area and with the Deer Park LEPC.  The
LEPC is using the information for a detailed review of the
city's emergency response plan.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-
Specific Prevention Steps
We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing
accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management
systems address each of the key features of successful
prevention programs including:

  -    Process Safety Information - Each of our processes have
     a comprehensive information package that is used to guide
     the choice of process and control technologies, operating
     parameters, and inspection intervals for equipment such as
     pipes, vessels, and protective systems.
-    HAZOP - These HAZOP's were and are used to define th
scenarios used in this report.  The accident scenarios found
in HAZOP's form the basis of additional analyses which allow
us to ensure that the integrity levels of all protective
systems are high enough to protect both our employees and
our neighbors.  They also help us target the most important
equipment for more frequent inspections.
-    Operating Pro

cedures - Operating procedures are in
place for all processes and include safety, checklists, and
guides for trouble shooting which allow technicians to keep
the processes out of unsafe areas.  Technicians are involved
in writing, reviewing, and updating operating instructions.
-    Training - Training is based on the operating
instructions.  Technicians are trained on all new or changed
systems, as well as re-qualified on all procedures at least
every 3 years.
-    Mechanical Integrity - We have a comprehensive
inspection and preventive maintenance system that ensures
that equipment maintains its capability to contain the
process chemicals.  This system is being continuously
improved.
-    Management of Change - We have a detailed, multi-level
MOC system that ensures that nothing is changed without
input, and that everyone involved knows about it.  Employees
at all levels are involved in the operation of the MOC
system.
-    Compliance Audits - Compliance audits are performed and
actions are entered into a computer based action tracking
system to make sure actions are closed in a timely manner
and it is available for everyone to see.
-    Incident Investigations - Incident investigations are
done on any accident, injury, process upset, or near miss.
We use the multi-cause, or root-cause analysis, and all
actions and results are tracked.  This information is used
to find the problem and make sure that it doesn't happen
again.
-    Employee Participation - Employees participate in all
aspects of the prevention program.  Employees are involved
in HAZOP's, MAPP's, Incident Investigations, and EHS
Reviews, or they don't happen.  Employees help write
procedures and assist in training.  Technicians and
mechanics are expected to attend MOC and EHS Reviews.
-    Contractors - Contractors are selected according to
stringent standards of management, competence, corporate
guidelines, and most importantly safety.  Contractors are
expected t

o adhere to the same standards of safety that our
own employees do.

Five-Year Accident History
We keep records of all significant accidental chemical
releases that occur at our facility.  The following brief
summary of accidental releases involving materials covered
under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:  Vinyl
Acetate - There have been no releases of VA that met the
criteria for the Five-Year Accident History.  Acrylonitrile
- There have been no releases of AN that met the criteria
for the Fie-Year History.


Emergency Response Plan
We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which
consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local
regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.
Our program provides the essential planning and training for
effectively protecting workers, the public, and the
environment during the emergency.  We not only have our own
plan and training, but we contract with the larger Rohm and
Haas Texas plant next door for Fire and Emergency Response
Services.  We also coordinate our plan with the community
emergency response plan.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The following is a list of improvements that we are panning
to implement at the facility to help prevent and/or better
respond to accidental chemical releases.

As of the time of submittal, we have a plan to take our fire
protection for the AN storage to the next level which
includes a permanent foam addition system.

Certifications
Within the past five years, the process has had no
accidental release that caused offsite impacts provided in
the RMP rule (40 CFR 68.10 (b) (1)).  No additional measures
are necessary to prevent offsite impacts from accidental
releases.  In the event of fire, explosion, or a release of
a regulated substance from the process, entry within the
distance to the specified endpoints may pose a danger to
public emergency responders.  Therefore, public emergency
responders should not enter this ar

ea except as arranged
with the emergency contact indicated in the RMP Plan.  The
undersigned certifies that, the best of my knowledge,
information, and belief, formed after reasonable inquiry,
this information submitted is true, accurate, and complete.

For all other covered processes, the undersigned also
certifies that, to the best of my knowledge, information,
and belief, formed after reasonable inquiry, the other
information submitted in this RMP Plan is true, accurate,
and comlete.

Printed Name:       David Willis
Signature:
Title:    EHS/Training/Quality Systems Manager
Date:     April 28, 2003
